To commemorate their 100th anniversary AmEx has researched 100 significant moments in business travel over the last century. This article on 1941. 
In 1941, amidst WWII, the need for medical supplies was becoming increasingly pressing. Great Britain was lacking in resources to widely produce penicillin, but knew it was an essential drug to provide Allied Forces on the battlefield. 
In July, pharmacologist, Howard Florey, and scientist, Norman Heatley, traveled from Oxford, England to the United States in an attempt to generate interest from American pharmaceutical companies for large-scale penicillin production. The pair first flew from England to neutral Portugal where they then boarded a Pan-Am Clipper seaplane bound for New York. The planeâ€™s windows were blacked out to appear inconspicuous on the perilous journey over an Atlantic Ocean patrolled by the German Navy. Florey and Heatley remained in the U.S. for several weeks to lobby for industry support. 1940s era Merck Co. Penicillin bottles and pharmaceutical plant. Oct 22, 2015
